title: M-TBLT-Based English Speaking and Experimental Results Presentation Improvement Program for Science Professionals

context.prior_knowledge: Basic English communication skills, understanding of fundamental scientific terminology (hypothesis, variables, experiments, measurement), and experience with university-level scientific inquiry methods
context.additional_context: Project execution based on scientific fieldwork experience (e.g., experimental design-analysis-conclusion) and real-time collaborative learning via mobile devices. Emphasis on presentation skills for systematically presenting scientific evidence.

learning_goals: Graduate students will create a 10-minute presentation incorporating complex sentence structures (conjunctions, relative clauses, participial phrases, etc.) to clearly articulate logical connections between experimental hypotheses, variables, and conclusions in scientific presentations and achieve ≥4 points (5-point scale) in the "logical coherence" category of peer evaluation rubrics.
Use scientific terminology (e.g., variables, measurement, analysis, evidence) and grammatical structures with ≥70% accuracy during academic presentations.
Demonstrate fluency (pruned speech rate) of ≥120 words per minute in professionally communicating experimental observations and scientific inquiry processes.
Form self-directed learning habits with ≥85% feedback incorporation rate using mobile collaboration tools and improve scientific evidence-based presentation materials.

resources: Science-themed project kits (experiment reports, research data samples, etc.)
constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
